comments.commentBody: It is a fact that one really has to desperate or out of one's mind to live under Trump's command. He can't fill offices because people won't work for him.

All I can say is that if the Russians had helped Hillary win the election and it was then discovered that members of her campaign had contact with the Russians before, during or after the campaign, impeachment hearings would have already begun!!

A big "Hiss" to Jeff Sessios is what I'd recommend, Gail. That's "Hiss" as in Alger Hiss, and Sessions deserves no better treatment than Congress offered Hiss.

Ironically, Sesions answered a question that Sen. Franken hadn't asked. Franken had actually asked Sessiins how, as AG, he might handle the news that someone, anyone, in the Trump campaign had had contact with the Russians.

Instead, Sessions leaped to his own defense -- Had he been coached to say this? -- and denied that he himself had had no such contacts.

I don't think it was an accident. And lying to Congress is a big no-no. Just ask Bill Clinton, whom they impeached over a more innocuous parsing of questions and responses (and relating to a less serious subject than the security of our national elections).
They say that although Sessions is singed he is not the fire at the center of the scandal.

I'm just having such a hard time with hypocrisy and the willful ostriching it takes to ignore it.

Hillary was corrupt and in Wall Street's thrall. But Trump put Wall Street in the cabinet. Hillary endangered national security with an e-mail server, but the Tweeter in Chief had national security sinking for the third time with his team having discussions with Russia. Hillary botched Benghazi, and downplayed it to help Obama win, but Trump botched Yemen. And Comey released the completely undamning information about Anthony Wiener's e-mail investigation, but sat on the problem of Trump's Russian connection.

Anything goes, as long as you win, because you can define the truth.

So why bother with investigators? The answer is already written, ready for release, without anything to back it up: "Nothing to see here, folks. Move along."

If I commit perjury, and called out for it, can I then write an explanation weeks later and expect all to be forgiven? This is the new " Sessions Perjury Retraction Rule" which is being adopted by the R's in congress. It will lead to an eradication of perjury - ah, only if we are caught. Will DeVos, Mnuchin, Price, and Pruitt need to use the new rule?

Yes, for sure, but Putin *believes* in his Big Important Man status. His self-esteem is rock solid. Trump is a case of arrested development. His behavior is so erratic because he is colossally insecure about whether he is actually Someone Important, and he's incapable of hiding his fear. That's why he has to bray and bellow so ceaselessly. You never see such embarrassing behavior from Putin.

What have we come to, when despite being a vicious murderer, the Russian president is far classier than our own.

We are investigating the wrong issues. The KGB plays the long game, not looking for easy and quick results. Trump was a perfect target to acquire as an asset. High profile, huge ego, financial problems. We must start the investigating by going back years into the Trump business interactions with the Russians. How many properties has Russians purchased from Trump and at what price. Was there times when Trump needed cash and Russians just happened to buy from him at inflated prices that allowed him to cover his debts with the profits? If any of this comes to light then it is reasonable to assume that he has been compromised. The Putin Mafia has so much money that a few million here and there would be an easy investment in an asset with the potential to disrupt our politics. There must be a through investigation into all of the Trump finances going back at least ten tears if not further. This is where the bodies are buried. What we are seeing now is only the surface of what has been a long term effort by the Russians to compromise Trump and turn him, and with his evident lack of curiosity and enormous ego it is possible that he hasn't even been aware of how they have used him. But the money will tell all.
The other side of this coin is the inspectors who weren't able to outsmart Uber's machinery.

I can walk out of a bar or restaurant and tap into my UBER app my wish to be picked up, and presto, a car arrives with minutes to take me a few block away. A taxi would have taken forever to arrive. I wish the busy-body regulators,  who are probably bought politicians doing the bidding of their donors would just butt out. It's a great service that is fulfilling a need.
Good for Uber. We are not subjects who must apologize for taking measures to avoid scrutiny by "authorities", we are a free and sovereign people.

I'm not a libertarian by any definition of the word, but the premise of this article is just stupid. Come on, NYT, grow up. There are no white hats here. You'd look a little less benighted if you followed the money. What's motivating these city officials in the first place? Have you collected any information on taxi cab companies and drivers' unions contributing campaign cash to the zealous city officials cracking down on Uber? If not, get it together and start doing it. It's an essential part of the story.
Who says either one is evil? Their wage structures are regrettable, surely, but so is MacDonalds'-- this is just much ado about nothing.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
The part of this that gets to me is that American cities think that they can outlaw or stop a business that people will use and pay for services.
When Red China outlaws something, the American cities doing the same thing should consider which crowd they really want to be a part of.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
Nut it's not illegal if it is something Cool People use, right?
That's pretty much what we heard when Mr. Obama ignored some laws he disagreed with and made up others because they were politically correct progressive things. Immigration is a good example.

Think it through John. Who passed those laws and how did they benefit? A better case could be made for violations in restraint of trade on the part of corrupt municipal officials who created these laws making Uber illegal.

Uh, pardon my nap. But this is how one conducts business in a crooked country, with no accountability, alternative facts, which pays 7 times more for transportation infrastructure than other developed nations, and 10 times more for medicine and medical care. Plus every existing sector in U.S. public transportation is absolutely hapless. So why is anyone surprised by all this? What does anyone even write about it? Alternative countries: Now that's the thing to be thinking about (even if most also have Uber, Uber is about to crash and burn).

You say that you want big government out of your life. If that is what you truly want, are you willing to do without the what big government services and regulations provided? Clean water, clean air, roads, waste disposal, basic retirement and health care safety nets, recreation in the form of national parks, national security, free speech, and the list goes on and on.
@Justin:  You're voting in favor of anarchy, then.
My vote is for Uber, not municipal bureaucrats trying to preserve inconvenient, unresponsive monopolies ...
Wow, I knew that they were aggressive, but this stuff is absolutely Looney Tunes. I'll pass on Uber next time I need a ride.
Do you have any idea how much Uber drivers take home after expenses relative to people who have to rent a medallion?  It seems to me they may be coming out ahead.

Why is the Left so completely obsessed with exposing Uber as some kind of a James Bond parody of an evil corporate empire, even while every card carrying liberal that I know uses Uber and loves it?  In every city where Uber is regulated or prohibited, the initial motivator - and in New York State outside of Manhattan, the sole motivator - is to protect the taxi monopoly and municipal licensing fees.  Everything else is pretext.  This is ironic, when it is established that Uber provides a public service, especially in cities with inadequate or downright scary cab service and poor public transportation, provides flexible employment for people looking for, well, flexible employment, and is much appreciated by millions of users.  If you lack your own car, try getting your way around most US cities without Uber.  Uber is a disruptive innovator of an industry that was overdue for disruptive change.  If Uber has found legal ways to work around dubious local regulations designed to protect the status quo, good for Uber.  Keep it up.

Since you are speaking from and for the Right, it appears, why are illegal actions described in the article not treated as needing punishment by the forces of law and order.  Is it that all laws can be broken or avoided if done in search of profit?  Outside of Manhattan a phone call to a service usually provides local transportation, local service can also be found at commuter train stations throughout the US.  But I guess that an international company with a cool app is much better and worthy of use and support regardless of their practices.  Uber keeps profiles on customers and associated contacts but refuses to fully look into driver backgrounds.  Sad

I don't consider myself a very "noble" person, i.e. my attitude towards a company doesn't really stop me from doing business with them. But I make a point not to use Uber, mostly because I like the thought that by using a taxi I'm helping a new immigrant make some money. I don't know, maybe that's a silly thing. But I like to think so.
Yes,  that is a silly thing. Immigrants are Uber drivers too,  and most money made from cabs goes to medallion owners not drivers.

I use Uber a lot because I can no longer drive but am otherwise quite active. At least 50% of the time my driver is , like me, an immigrant,  Cabs are dirty and unreliable. Uber is prompt, clean, polite and affordable since I got rid of my car. They often have very interesting stories. My life, not to mention my marriage, would be miserable without it.
No. Lyft is the Costco to Uber's Wal-Mart. In other words: caring, progressive and in possession of a functioning conscience.
